content.user_title: Add Plate.js rich text editors to React apps
content.value_statement: Building rich text editors from scratch is complex and time-consuming. This skill provides step-by-step guidance for implementing Plate.js editors, from simple comment inputs to full-featured document editors with headings, lists, and media support.
actual_capabilities: Install Plate.js components via shadcn CLI commands
Create simple editors for comments, chat, and short text with basic formatting
Build detailed editors with headings, blockquotes, and lists
Configure toolbars with formatting buttons and mark controls
Implement state management for editor content using value and onChange props
Follow best practices for plugin registration and component architecture
limitations: Provides implementation guidance only, not pre-built components
Requires existing shadcn/ui setup in the target project
Does not cover server-side rendering or backend storage implementation
Assumes basic familiarity with React and TypeScript

output_examples.input: Add a simple editor for comments with basic formatting
output: Install core package: pnpm dlx shadcn@latest add @plate/editor
Install basic nodes: pnpm dlx shadcn@latest add @plate/basic-nodes-kit
Add FixedToolbar with MarkToolbarButton components for each format
Set up EditorContainer with placeholder text and styling

output_examples.input: Build a blog editor with headings and blockquotes
output: Install editor-basic preset for comprehensive setup
Configure plugins: H1Plugin, H2Plugin, H3Plugin, BlockquotePlugin
Register custom components using withComponent() method
Create toolbar with separate sections for elements and marks
Implement onChange handler to capture editor value as JSON

output_examples.input: What file structure should I use for my editor components?
output: Create src/components/plate-editor directory for custom editors
Place simple-editor.tsx for basic comment/chat implementations
Place detailed-editor.tsx for full document/blog editors
Keep base UI components in src/components/ui (managed by shadcn)
Import editor, fixed-toolbar, and toolbar components from ui directory

best_practices: Use withComponent() when registering plugins that render custom elements like headings and blockquotes
Store editor content as JSON using onChange callback rather than HTML for better security and flexibility
Install base UI components via shadcn CLI to ensure consistency with your existing design system
anti_patterns: Avoid dangerouslySetInnerHTML for editable content; use Plate value prop and JSON serialization instead
Do not skip component registration for plugins that render custom elements or they will not display correctly
Avoid hardcoding toolbar layouts; use the FixedToolbar and FloatingToolbar components for proper structure

faq.question: Does Plate.js work with Next.js applications?
faq.answer: Yes, use 'use client' directive since Plate.js requires client-side rendering. All editor components must be client components in Next.js.

faq.question: What is the difference between simple and detailed editors?
faq.answer: Simple editors have basic marks like bold and italic. Detailed editors include block elements like headings, lists, quotes, tables, and media.

faq.question: How do I save editor content to a database?
faq.answer: Use the onChange prop to capture the value as JSON. Serialize to your preferred format (JSON, HTML, or markdown) before storing in your database.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: This skill only provides implementation guidance and documentation. It does not access your files, make network requests, or execute code.

faq.question: Why is my toolbar not appearing in the editor?
faq.answer: Ensure FixedToolbar is placed inside the Plate provider component and that toolbar button components are properly imported from shadcn/ui directory.

faq.question: How does Plate.js compare to other editors like Slate or TipTap?
faq.answer: Plate.js is built on Slate architecture with a plugin-based approach. It integrates well with shadcn/ui and provides excellent TypeScript support.
